newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish coalition conservative says polls this year.
newsitem.headline: Turkish coalition conservative says polls this year.

text.p: The Turkish government's conservative coalition partners said on Monday early elections would be held this year under a deal with Islamist Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan.
"This election will be carried out by the end of 1997," Hasan Ekinci, deputy chairman of the True Path Party, told a news conference.
Erbakan, Turkey's first Islamist leader, announced on Sunday he would step down in favour of True Path leader Tansu Ciller within a month.

He said Foreign Minister Ciller would then head a caretaker government to go to elections, but set no date. Istanbul stocks shrugged off the possibility of early polls, rising 4.51 percent in morning trade.
Pressure from the generals to carry out an anti-Islamist crackdown had brought the 11-month-old coalition to breaking point.

Ekinci said the two coalition parties had no specific date in mind for elections, normally due by the year 2000. Turkish press reports say Erbakan, 70, wants a quick poll, but U.S.-trained economist Ciller had wanted a date next spring.

Turkish newspapers said on Monday that President Suleyman Demirel, who would have a key role in any power handover, may throw a spanner in the works of a transition. He reportedly said there was no clear mechanism for handing the prime minister's office to a coalition partner.
Demirel departed for a four-day visit to the Baltic republics on Monday.
